4.00.text: The moment I was selected was

5.44.text: the greatest experience of my life.

7.96.text: What a privilege it was to have

10.24.text:
the support of the House to do that
job.

12.88.text: And what a pleasure it was for me

14.00.text: all those years to be in that role.

15.44.text: I loved every minute of it.

17.48.text:
I was never very conscious
of being a woman.

19.28.text: I was born a woman, but I can work,

21.44.text:
and I can do this job just
as much as a man can do it.

24.32.text: I was part of the House of Commons.

27.16.text:
I was conducting the
proceedings of the House.

29.84.text:
It didn't matter to me
whether I wore a skirt.

32.00.text: I wore a skirt, and I was a woman.

33.00.text:
But I didn't have any
feelings about that at all.

35.76.text:
Whether the Members did
or not, I'm not sure.

40.16.text:
I felt, in the early days, they felt
that well,

43.12.text:
"She's a woman; she'd roll
over like a pussy cat."

46.52.text:
"We can get what we want;
so many points of order."

48.76.text:
And this is where, I think,
the steeliness comes in.

51.16.text: Give them an inch, and then they'll

52.76.text:
hang themselves is what
I thought about it.

54.68.text:
- Madam Speaker, given
the fact that the Craven

56.80.text:
attitude of Members opposite
towards those rail unions

59.48.text: who have caused such an enormous...

62.92.text:
The Honourable Gentleman will
resume his seat immediately.

68.52.text: I shall name the Honourable Member.

71.08.text:
What I was very conscious about
was

73.60.text:
I had to do the job to
the best of my ability,

76.56.text:
because I couldn't let my own sex
down.

79.60.text:
The other feeling too was that
I had to do well in the Chair

82.44.text:
because I was the first
Speaker to come from the

86.44.text:
opposition benches, which
is hugely important to me.

90.04.text:
- The main question is
that Miss Betty Boothroyd

94.16.text:
do take the Chair of
this House as Speaker.

97.68.text:
As many as are of that opinion, say
"Aye."

104.20.text:
- It seems to me, there's
always been the tradition

108.84.text:
so I wasn't surprised when I was
asked

112.88.text:
And the choice of the artist,
really, was left to me.

116.20.text:
I knew it was an area I know little
about,

118.24.text:
but I did examine what
other artists had done,

120.68.text:
and I liked the work of
Andrew Festing very much.

123.44.text:
And I was glad to meet
him, and he was very good

125.36.text:
at doing my face and
hands and toes and things,

128.56.text:
and I was amused because
he took the robes,

130.96.text: the gold robes, home at the weekend,

133.04.text:
and his wife stuffed
the shape of a mannequin

136.00.text:
in the bathroom and with bath
towels,

139.56.text:
and he put the robe over there,
and he painted it like that.

142.44.text:
So it didn't take him very long to
do me.

146.16.text:
Well, together, Andrew Festing
and I chose the backdrop

149.12.text: which is the Monarch's bed which I

150.92.text:
treasured very much in the State
Rooms.

153.88.text:
But, also, it depicts my coat
of arms, which I enjoyed,

159.64.text:
which shows the white rose of
Yorkshire I was very proud of,

163.24.text: the Speaker's mace going through it,

166.64.text:
and the millrinds which
represent West Bromwich,

171.40.text: and the wise old owl of my school,

174.56.text:
But the saving grace, the
lovely thing about that,

177.28.text:
is that it is a diamond,
because it was said in heraldry

180.72.text: that women could not have shields,

183.00.text:
which is a load of nonsense of
course,

184.76.text: so I had to have a diamond.

185.96.text:
But on top of that diamond is a
green bow,

188.88.text: which you have to depict in heraldry

192.88.text: It says, "The forget me not bow"

196.64.text:
The motto I chose is
hugely important to me

198.92.text:
because it represents,
I think, so much of me.

202.44.text:
I'm not a person who makes long
speeches,

204.48.text:
I come to the point,
I'm very North Country,

207.48.text: I am very direct with people,

209.92.text:
and it sums up, I think, my
personality.

212.28.text:
I only speak when I've
got something to say,

214.32.text: and when I've something to say,

216.24.text: I am trying to serve my country

218.08.text: and to serve the philosophy that

219.20.text:
I cherish very much: "I speak to
serve."

226.12.text:
As for the portrait
itself, I quite like it,

228.08.text: but I think I look rather benign,

231.16.text: rather sweet and long-tempered and very gracious,

234.96.text: where it doesn't show my steeliness.

237.16.text: But, of course, a portrait is

238.60.text: in the eye of the artist, isn't it?

240.84.text:
But it was a great
privilege to serve the House

242.68.text:
for all those years, to have
the confidence of the House,

246.08.text: and to do a job that I did, too.

248.36.text:
It's a place that I love, and I was
hugely

250.76.text:
privileged and happy to have that
role.
